|wi2_if_name = |rad2chip1 = MediaTek;MT7615N; |rad2oui = <!-- Only if different from above OUI --> |rad2_ant_conn = <!-- Leave blank for unknown --> |rad2txchains = 4 |rad2rxchains = 4 |rad2sstreams = 4 |rad2stand = IEEE 802.11a/n/ac |rad2ac = 1733 |rad2n = 600 |rad2a = 54 |rad2freq = 5
}}{{TIDTOC|embedded}} ==Overview== FCC docs indicate a 4T4R 5G radio, but I'm unsure of actual specifications...
"LWW529-A1-BL REV.015" seems to be silkscreened on the board in the FCC photos. It may be manufactured by '''CyberTAN'''.
==Links of Interest== *[http://www.linksys.com/us/support-article?articleNum=207544 ''Getting to know the Linksys EA7300''] *[https://www.digit.in/networking/linksys-ea7500-max-stream-ac1900-wi-fi-router-review-124847.html ''Same Circuit Design as the Linksys EA7500 v2''] {{See also|Linksys EA7500 v2|Linksys EA7400 v2}}
==Flashing== {{Flashnotice}} ===Flashing OpenWrt=== {{OpenWrt |techdata = https://openwrt.org/toh/hwdata/linksys/linksys_ea7300_v2 |wikipage = https://openwrt.org/toh/linksys/ea7300_v2 |forumpage = |forumpage2 = |forumpage3 = |github = |target = ramips |subtarget = mt7621 |arch = mipsel_24kc |support_started_version = 21.02.0 |current_supported_version = <!-- auto --> |unsupportedfuncntions = |comment = }} Please insert instructions here
==See also== Linksys EA7300 V2 Router. .. Help to Identify 6 pin chip. I need help to ID a 6 pin (probably sot-23-6) chip under different marking... I have purchased a lot of 30 (for parts) Routers of of eBay, 15 of them has a 6 pin chip shorted. Same ship, different marking. 1x=S13 1x=F4W 1x=R2G Its a very small chip, about 1.08mm by 1.90mm. It shows different voltage on different pins on a working unit. Thanks in advance¡ [[File:1x=S13.jpg|246px|IDing chip on a EA7300 V2 ]] [[File:Linksys EA7300 v2 pcb top.jpg|350px|pcb top]]
=== Router repair after a thunderstorm === I repaired such a router after a thunderstorm, replacing the CPU and one DC/DC. I used an analog RT7295D. The circuit is drawn from the board, for selecting analogues of a failed dc/dc converter. The difference between this microcircuit and the original on the board is the operating frequency. Analog 500 kHz, original 1.5 MHz. The router has been working for several years.
[[File:Schematic.jpg|246px|chip RT7295D]]
[[Category:English Documentation]]
